articles.headline: MetLife Wins Battle to Remove ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label
articles.snippet: MetLife has been fighting since 2014 to remove the designation because of the extra regulatory scrutiny it brings.
articles.abstract: MetLife has been fighting since 2014 to remove the designation because of the extra regulatory scrutiny it brings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Opponents of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul won an important battle on Wednesday as a federal judge here stripped the “too big to fail” label from the insurance company MetLife.

articles.headline: Corporations Grow Nervous About Participating in Republican Convention
articles.snippet: The companies are facing pressure from civil rights groups to stay away from the Cleveland convention, given the emergence of Donald J. Trump as the probable nominee.
articles.abstract: The companies are facing pressure from civil rights groups to stay away from the Cleveland convention, given the emergence of Donald J. Trump as the probable nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s best-known corporations are nervously grappling with what role they should play at the Republican National Convention, given the likely nomination of Donald J. Trump, whose divisive candidacy has alienated many women, blacks and Hispanics.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Facebook’s Live Videos Get Lots of Looks but No Money Yet
articles.snippet: Despite the appeal of the nascent product, any revenue gain for broadcasters remains a vague promise.
articles.abstract: Despite the appeal of the nascent product, any revenue gain for broadcasters remains a vague promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: When severe weather passed through the Atlanta area early this month, Brad Nitz, a meteorologist for a local television station, WSB-TV, fed viewers live video updates on the station’s website, as he has done for years.
articles.byline: By John Herrman and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Donald Trump, Abortion Foe, Eyes ‘Punishment’ for Women, Then Recants
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, pressed on his support for an abortion ban, envisioned “some form of punishment” for women having the procedure. Hours later, he revised himself.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, pressed on his support for an abortion ban, envisioned “some form of punishment” for women having the procedure. Hours later, he revised himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that women who seek abortions should be subject to “some form of punishment” if the procedure is banned in the United States, further elevating Republican concerns that his explosive remarks about women could doom the party in the fall.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: With Romance Novels Booming, Beefcake Sells, but It Doesn’t Pay
articles.snippet: This corner of the book world is red hot and among the most innovative, with e-books and apps, and it needs a steady stream of fresh-faced cover models.
articles.abstract: This corner of the book world is red hot and among the most innovative, with e-books and apps, and it needs a steady stream of fresh-faced cover models.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — Jason Aaron Baca is good-looking, not handsome like the Ryans (Gosling and Reynolds) or rugged like Daniel Craig, who is fetching in a tailored Tom Ford suit. But when Mr. Baca, 42, slipped on a pair of dark aviator glasses recently, he looked remarkably like Tom Cruise in “Top Gun.”

articles.headline: Signs of Wisconsin Backlash Against Donald Trump, Who Trails in Poll
articles.snippet: The Stop Trump movement may never have another opportunity like the one in Wisconsin, where resistance to Mr. Trump was high even before his latest controversies.
articles.abstract: The Stop Trump movement may never have another opportunity like the one in Wisconsin, where resistance to Mr. Trump was high even before his latest controversies.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — The danger signs are mounting for Donald J. Trump in Wisconsin: Right-wing radio hosts are flaying him, Gov. Scott Walker and other elected Republicans have endorsed Senator Ted Cruz, and a new poll showed Mr. Cruz with a 10-percentage-point lead in the state before Tuesday’s primary.

articles.headline: ISIS Turns Saudis Against the Kingdom, and Families Against Their Own
articles.snippet: Adopting elements of a Sunni creed known as Wahhabism, the Islamic State has recruited Saudis to kill their own relatives and to bomb mosques.
articles.abstract: Adopting elements of a Sunni creed known as Wahhabism, the Islamic State has recruited Saudis to kill their own relatives and to bomb mosques.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURAIDA, Saudi Arabia — The men were not hardened militants. One was a pharmacist, another a heating and cooling technician. One was a high school student.
